title: I have just started reading political science. I need a good command over PSIR in order to strengthen my optional. How can I proceed further? - Quora

response.answer_text: I really feel that there’s so much to read in political science, you cant handle it without a coaching unless you’ve done your graduation in it. But I warn you, this answer might be a little biased since I’m a pol sci graduate myself. So I joined Shubhra Ranjan Ma’am’s coaching classes at Vajiram. I really dont know if it’s worth the 44k (read it’s not). They say she’s the only one who can teach it right. But her notes were very useful when I gave my JNU entrance. I know a couple friends who recorded all the lectures. I’d recommend read the basic books- Bipan Chandra, Guha etc and religiously read the newspaper. You’ll soon notice you’ll start connecting theories and actual things that happen in real life. Now keep in mind- the syllabus is vast. You HAVE to make a plan and stick to it. It would be pretty tough to make your own notes-how much time do you have? Since it’s so vast- you have to just fall in love with the subject and be loyal to it. You have to be interested. When reading the philosopher my trick is to be the philosopher and think like him in his times. Justify everything the philosopher says to yourself as absurd as it may seem then (like Plato’s communism of wives.). Dont question him till you’re done understanding the entire idea or concept you’ve picked up- the philosopher is god for that time being. Then once you’re done- then the criticisms are pretty obvious. Everyone loves IR. It’s the most popular one. But remember you have to relate the theories with the real life happenings to understand the dynamics of the theory. Plus it helps you with your pres too as far as I think (could be wrong). Polity for pre, laxmikant is best. But Ma’am said that it gets the spirit of the constitution wrong (like calling the Governor agent of the PM/President sometimes). So I’d be careful about that. Btw, why worried about optional abhi. What’s up with your Pre prepz?

Starting with INT. RELATIONS books that are good and easy to understand includes- 1. Globalization of world politics by baylis and smith.2.Global politics by andrew heywood. these would be sufficient for Int relations.Then for political science paper1 political theory you should read o.p gauba and andrew heywood, for indian political thought go for V.r mehta.For indian govt and politics go B.L.fadia , d.d basu.In part 2 for comparative ignou notes are ok
